sections.heading: Environmental significance statement
sections.text:
Biofouling is one of the most challenging problems for maritime industry. Stateof-art approaches are focused in coatings containing efficient but toxic biocides. Recently, an innovative approach included biocides encapsulation (e.g. DCOIT, Ag) in silica nanocapsules (SiNC) promoting their controlled release under specific conditions with environmental benefits. The present study provides the first holistic toxicity assessment of novel (SiNCAg, SiNC-DCOIT-Ag) and state-of-art anti-fouling nanomaterials (SiNC-DCOIT), carried out in early stages of (nano)materials development. Globally, exposure tests demonstrated the protective effect of the encapsulation process in several non-target species, without compromising the required AF efficacy against target species, comparing with free biocides. Thus, these “smart” engineered nanomaterials may be regarded as promising efficient and eco-friendly alternatives to tackle biofouling.

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Biofouling is one of the most challenging problems for maritime industry that
has been minimized through the application of coatings containing anti-fouling
(AF) biocides (e.g. Cu-based compounds; DCOIT) in immersed structures. An
innovative eco-friendly approach based on the encapsulation of AF biocides in
engineered nanomaterials (e.g. silica mesoporous nanocapsules (SiNC)) has
recently been applied to control the leaching rate and the environmental
impacts of AF biocides when used as additives in coatings. Thus, the present
study aims to: (a) assess the toxicity towards marine species of three innovative
AF nanomaterials: SiNC loaded with DCOIT (SiNC-DCOIT); SiNC coated with
silver (SiNC-Ag); SiNC loaded with DCOIT and coated with silver (SiNC-DCOIT-
Ag)) and free counterparts (DCOIT, ionic silver and empty SiNC) and (b) test if
encapsulation reduces the toxicity of biocides to non-target species maintaining
the anti-fouling efficacy against target species. To achieve this goal, eleven
marine species (three target and eight non-target) were exposed to the test
compounds, following standard protocols, with adaptations for some species.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Biofouling corresponds to an ecological succession of fouling organisms (e.g.,
bacteria, diatoms, barnacles, mussels) in submerged surfaces. In human-made
structures (e.g., vessels, bridges, ships), biofouling causes extensive
environmental and economic negative impacts worldwide, such as: (a) an
increase in the vessels’ weight and hulls’ roughness and consequent increase
of frictional drag, fuel consumption and CO2 emissions; (b) an increase of the mass of fixed installations; (c) interference on the normal buoyancy of floating
devices; (d) reduction of the durability of submerged structures; and (e)
dispersion of invasive species through ballast water or ships’ hulls around the world.1–3
Anti-fouling biocides have been commonly used as additives in coatings to
protect submerged structures from the undesirable adhesion of fouling organisms.4,5 Organotin compounds were the most worldwide used and
effective class of anti-fouling agents, until 2008, year they were banned due to their toxic and biomagnification effects.2,6,7 A new generation of biocides (e.g.
Copper Pyrithione, Diuron, Zineb, Ziram, DCOIT, etc.) with lower toxicity and
persistence in the environment has been used to replace organotin compounds.5,8,9 The booster biocide 4,5-dichloro-2-octyl-4-isothiazolin-3-one
(abbreviated as DCOIT and commercially known as Sea-Nine™ 211N, Parmetol® S15 or Kathon™910 SB) has been considered as a promising
solution with a broad-spectrum action and low environmental risk, being biologically degraded in seawater in less than 24 hours.10,11 However, booster biocides are still of concern due to their effects on non-target species11,12, especially at lower levels of marine food chains.1,9,13 As an example, cybutryne

sections.heading: 2. Experimental

2.1.Nanomaterials synthesis
Six chemical compounds were tested in the present study, (a) two biocides
(DCOIT and silver nitrate (AgNO3)), (b) unloaded/”empty” silica mesoporous nanocapsules (SiNC) and (c) three engineered nanomaterials with anti-fouling
properties, corresponding to SiNC loaded with one or two biocides (SiNC-
DCOIT, SiNC-Ag and SiNC-DCOIT-Ag). These nanocontainers were prepared
through an oil-in-water microemulsion containing the surfactant CTAB (cetyl
trimethylammonium bromide), that served as the emulsion stabilizer and
template for the condensation of TEOS (tetraethyl orthosilicate), followed by the hydrolysis and condensation of TEOS at the microemulsion’s interface.17,18 The
encapsulation of DCOIT in SiNC was prepared in an oil-in-water solution by
adding ammonia solution and DCOIT diluted in xylene to an aqueous solution
containing CTAB, being the last step the addition of TEOS to the reactional
media. Silver immobilization on SiNC was performed by suspending SiNC or

2.3.Ecotoxicity testing
A total of eleven species were used to assess effects of the 6 chemical
compounds’ exposure: the bacteria Vibrio fischeri, the microalgae Isochrysis
galbana and Nannochloropsis gaditana, the diatom Phaeodactylum tricornutum,
the rotifer Brachionus plicatilis, the bivalves Mytilus galloprovincialis and
Cerastoderma edule, the polychaete Hediste diversicolor, the crustaceans
Artemia salina and Palaemon varians and the echinoderm Paracentrotus
lividus. Three of these species (V. fischeri, P. tricornutum, and M.
galloprovincialis) are regarded as target species since they are representative
of fouling groups (bacteria, diatoms and mussels, respectively) that play an
important role along the biofouling process and, thus, can give an indication of

collected from reference areas in Portugal, and brought to the Department of
Biology of the University of Aveiro (Portugal), and acclimated for 72 h with

galloprovincialis (2–3 cm length) were collected at Costa Nova beach, Portugal

3.2.Ecotoxicity
The toxicity data (L/E/IC50) and the toxicity ratios between the encapsulated and the free compounds are summarized in Table 1 and 2, respectively (sigmoidal
curves that support these results can be consulted in Figure S4 and Figure S5).
All tested compounds had a concentration-dependent effect on the evaluated

concentration of each compound increased.
The unloaded SiNC was the less toxic compound, being still classified as
harmful to V. fischeri, M. galloprovincialis, H. diversicolor, and P. varians and

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
4.1.Unloaded nanomaterials
The present study showed that the unloaded silica nanocapsules were less
toxic than the loaded silica nanocapsules with anti-fouling biocides, in
agreement with other recent studies using unloaded SiNC and SINC loaded with zinc and copper pyrithiones18,21. These studies demonstrated that among
all tested species (Tetraselmis chuii, P. tricornutum, Bugula neritina and
Brachidontes pharaonis), the most sensitive species to SiNC was the bryzoan
B. neritina, which participates in intermediate key stages of the biofouling
process, highlighting the potential use of SiNC as a nanocarrier for biocides.
The information regarding the use of SiNC for anti-fouling purposes is still
scarce. However, this nanomaterial has been extensively studied for biotechnology, health, and medical purposes.32–34 In this sense, silicon and
silica nanoparticles have been highlighted as having high stability, versatility, biodegradability, biocompatibility and low toxicity.32,35–38 Nevertheless, the
present study unveiled that SiNC was more toxic to some of the species tested
than other engineered nanomaterials used for the same purpose, namely LDH.18,20,21 As theorized in recent studies17–19, SiNC toxicity may be related to
the presence of the surfactant CTAB, used in the synthesis of this nanomaterial,
rather than the large-sized agglomerates/aggregates formed in saltwater with

4.2.Anti-fouling biocides
Present findings confirm the extremely high efficacy of both biocides towards
the target species, namely the bacteria V. fischeri, the diatom P. tricornutum
and the mussel M. galloprovincialis. Bacteria and diatoms are the main groups
of organisms that firstly adhere to the submerged surfaces during the biofouling
process while mussels are one of the last groups of macrofoulers to settle. The
present results are in agreement with previous studies in which low
concentrations of DCOIT and silver were also deleterious for other target organisms, such as diatoms, macroalgae, crustaceans, and bivalves.10,40–45 An
ideal biocide should be effective in preventing the fixation of fouler species and
simultaneously should have low toxicity to non-target species, low bioaccumulation in the food web, and no persistence in the environment.10

characteristics, especially broad-spectrum action and rapid degradation into less toxic compounds.9,10,46 However, some authors argue that DCOIT’s

4.3.Anti-fouling nanomaterials
The direct use of biocides in paints may pose several risks for non-target
species due to the fast lixiviation. Therefore, to minimize this problem and to
improve the efficacy of current solutions towards target species, state-of-the-art

immobilization of a corrosion inhibitor in anionic-exchange nanoclays (LDH)

This technique was also already successfully applied for anti-fouling purposes, through the encapsulation of Zn and Cu pyrithiones in LDH and SiNC.18,21
Avelelas et al. demonstrated that the encapsulation of biocides reduced their

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
The present study demonstrated that the encapsulation of biocides in ENMs is a
promising eco-friendly strategy to develop innovative anti-fouling compounds
decreasing hazard to the environment compared to the booster biocides,
without compromising their efficacy. Moreover, based on the present findings,
SiNC-DCOIT-Ag can be considered the best AF biocidal product, with better
efficacy than SiNC-DCOIT and SiNC-Ag and even than free DCOIT and free Ag+. However, despite less toxic than both free biocides, SiNC-DCOIT-Ag is still
toxic to non-target species, with unpredictable long-term toxicity or
bioaccumulation effects. On the other hand, empty SiNC and SiNC-Ag were the
less toxic ENMs. Although less toxic against non-target species, SiNC and
SiNC-Ag materials proved to have also lower anti-fouling efficacy comparing
with SiNC-DCOIT and SiNC-DCOIT-Ag. These results show that the
encapsulation of AF biocides in SiNC is a promising technique, the surfactant
choice is crucial, as shown here by the toxicity of CTAB as an emulsion
stabilizer.

metadata.abstractText: Biofouling is one of the most challenging problems for maritime industry that has been minimized through the application of coatings containing anti-fouling (AF) biocides (e.g. Cu-based compounds; DCOIT) in immersed structures. An innovative eco-friendly approach based on the encapsulation of AF biocides in engineered nanomaterials (e.g. silica mesoporous nanocapsules (SiNC)) has recently been applied to control the leaching rate and the environmental impacts of AF biocides when used as additives in coatings. Thus, the present study aims to: (a) assess the toxicity towards marine species of three innovative AF nanomaterials: SiNC loaded with DCOIT (SiNC-DCOIT); SiNC coated with silver (SiNC-Ag); SiNC loaded with DCOIT and coated with silver (SiNC-DCOITAg)) and free counterparts (DCOIT, ionic silver and empty SiNC) and (b) test if encapsulation reduces the toxicity of biocides to non-target species maintaining the anti-fouling efficacy against target species. To achieve this goal, eleven marine species (three target and eight non-target) were exposed to the test compounds, following standard protocols, with adaptations for some species.
